entry.title: Uptime Customizing for Finance Conversion (UCFC)/CustOnTmp
entry.content:
What is CustOnTmp : The downtime-optimized conversion (doC) executes the FIN data conversion on the temporary instance during the uptime. For this, SUM needs the FIN Customizing to apply it prior to the data conversion. Until now, this required a standard conversion run prior to each doC run. In this standard run, the FIN Customizing was created and added to a transport request. Such a transport request is required to be provided to each doC run.

With the new feature Uptime Customizing for Finance Conversion, FIN delta Customizing activities can be performed directly on the temporary instance of the doC run. With this, the number of required standard conversion runs is reduced to one standard conversion at the beginning of the project. All FIN delta Customizing activities can be directly done on the temporary instance of the doC run. For each new doC iteration, the initial FIN Customizing transport request is used (created in standard conversion) together with all the delta Customizing transport requests prepared with each new iteration.  It is no longer required to always run a standard conversion before each doC cycle

Prerequisites 

  • Target release SAP S/4HANA 2022 (or higher)
  • DOC with database migration (so no in place conversion; migration is possible also for source on SAP HANA)
  • SUM 2.0 SP 23 (or higher)

Differences Between Standard doC and Uptime Customizing

The uptime customizing will by default add most application tables to the uptime handling automatically. This means, the manual selection of tables for uptime migration becomes mostly obsolete. The SUM will no longer display the respective section on downtime-optimized DMO (with file specification "table list"). If there are still tables which cause a significant runtime during phase EU_CLONE_MIG_DT_RUN they can still be added manually using CRRTABLIST.LST as in regular doC approach.

Every application table in uptime handling gets either a replication trigger or a freeze trigger in the source system.

The reasons for a freeze trigger are:

  • Customizing table with delivery class C, E or G
  • Static classification in SUM which requires a read-only restriction

Freeze Trigger 

Freeze triggers are needed to ensure the consistency of the uptime conversion. Freeze triggers are used in 3 different ways as below

  • Hard Freeze 

Freeze triggers are used to prevent customizing changes in the source system which might influence and invalidate the uptime conversion which is done in parallel to production on the temporary instance. This means that the number of freeze tables is significantly higher as in regular doC approach, although it should not add additional business restrictions as most of the freeze triggers are defined on pure customizing table which are not changed directly in a productive system. Nevertheless, the Impact analysis is of a higher importance for the doC with Uptime Customizing for Finance Conversion approach. The hard freeze will be activated during the preparation in phase SQLDB_FREEZE_TRIG_MODE_SWITCH_SMIG_TCR and will remain until the end of the doC procedure.

Please refer the   to SAP Note 2481983 - SUM Impact Analysis for downtime-optimized DMO

  • Temporary Freeze 

Some tables only be set read-only for a short period of time, for example while the Asset Accounting is prepared for the Uptime Conversion.

  • Freeze on Temporary System 

There will be freeze triggers used on the temporary instance between the SUM phases RUN_SMIG_SFIN_CUST_ON_TEMP_FREEZE and RUN_SMIG_SFIN_CUST_ON_TEMP_FREEZE_REV.

As tables must only be changed either by production operation (business users on system) on source system or by the customizing activities on the temporary system, all tables which can be changed by production operation will be set to read-only on the temporary system to avoid conflicting changes. It is, therefore, possible that a Customizing activity on the temporary instance fails with a short dump. In this case, create an incident  on component BC-UPG-DTM-TLA to clarify the access.

Some tables can be changed on source system and temporary system. Additionally, it is ensured that this does not cause a conflict or there is a special handling implementation like for number ranges. For more information, refer to section 3.1 Number Ranges in this SAP Note.

Execution 

During each doC execution, you must check in phase REQ_DOCMAX_DELTA_CUSTOMIZING that the provided FIN customizing that was added via CTI buffer is still valid.

doC with Uptime Customizing for Finance Conversion allows to add additional Customizing directly shortly before the uptime phase PARRUN_SMIG_SFIN. To do so, perform the following steps:

  1. SUM will stop in dialog phaseâ€¯REQ_DOCMAX_DELTA_CUSTOMIZING.
  2. Perform the IMG activities listed under "IMG/Conversion of Accounting to SAP S/4HANA / Preparations and Migration of Customizing" in each relevant client. Use transaction SPRO in the respective clients to perform the needed customizing steps.
    Note: to identify if there are any delta customizing activities required, the customizing activities must be executed step by step (this information can't be provided by the tool).

        Remark: The Customizing activities must be strictly restricted to the required Finance conversion Customizing.                                         3.  Start the uptime FIN conversion by continuing SUM

 Restricted tables for Uptime Handling

The following tables must not be added manually to uptime using CRRTABLIST.LST to avoid potential issues during Delta Customizing for the S/4HANA Finance Conversion.

BALHDR, BALDAT and BAL_INDX

Customizing on the Temporary Instance

  • Preparation of Number Range â€œRF_BELEGâ€ for New Document Type for Postings in Controlling

When using the Uptime Customizing for Finance Conversion approach, the preparation of data migration requires a new document type for postings in Controlling that considers also a new number range object â€œRF_BELEGâ€.

Available options for Number Range Number definition for controlling document type:

  • In target system(S/4HANA):After SFIN Data Migration completion, before releasing the system to business users (the recommended one)
  • During S/4HANA Standard Customizing preparation with the inclusion into the FI customizing transport request of the CO number ranges numbers;

In source system (ECC): Before the start of S/4HANA technical activities

  • Preparations and Migration of Customizing for Controlling

Maintain Operating Concern (KEA0)â€ on the temporary instance is not possible due to read-only restriction on table TKES2 and CEFORMT. Execute â€œMaintain Operating Concernâ€ only after SFIN delta migration is completed, as an after-migration activity, outside of SUM tool.

Restrictions

Depreciation calculation: Due to a read-only restriction on table T093D it is not allowed to run depreciation calculation when triggers are active in the system. This restriction only applies if table T093D is a logical pool table. If a mitigation is needed for this restriction you can get in contact with SUM development team raising an incident on BC-UPG-DTM-TLA.

 

Reference Notes:

3428570 - Executing and Monitoring Downtime-Optimized Conversion to SAP S/4HANA with Customizing on Temporary System


3388323 Executing and Monitoring Downtime-Optimized Conversion to SAP S/4HANA with SUM 2.0 SP 19

Other Important Links :

SAP Support Portal: http://support.sap.com/sltoolset 

SAP Help Portal: Preprocessing | SAP Help Portal.

SAP Help Portal: Customizing Freeze | SAP Help Portal.

Downtime-Optimized Conversion (Doc) for SAP S/4HANA... - SAP Community

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit â€“ Migrate Directly from SAP â€“ Increase flexibility using Split Logic
entry.content:
Hi all, 

Have you ever wondered how to create multiple entries in a target parameter of the target API using just one source table entry? Have you ever had the requirement to migrate one material to multiple plants although the material is only available in one plant in your source SAP system?  

With SAP S/4HANA 2025, a new feature is available for the S/4HANA Migration Cockpit called "Split Logic", which can be accessed using the Migration Object Modeler (transaction LTMOM). Note that this feature is only available for the migration approach "Migrate Data Directly from SAP System". 

Usually, one entry is created in the target parameter for each assigned source table entry. Using the "Split Logic" feature, you can define a split for the source table to create multiple entries in the target parameter for each source table entry.  

There are two types of split logic - simple split logic and advanced split logic. You can use simple split logic to create a fixed number of entries in the target parameter for each source table entry. Using the advanced split logic, you have a flexible way of defining the number of splits using rules. 

You have then the possibility to define different field mapping information for each of the so-called "splits". 

Some use cases for split logic include: 

  • Creating multiple entries in the target parameter based on one source entry (for example if you want to create a material in multiple plants, whereas previously the material was only available in one plant in the source system) 
  • Handling more complex migration requirements, for example if data in the source system is stored differently than in the target API. 

 We highly recommend reading our recently published SAP Note 3595079 for more information about this topic. 

 Let us know how you might use the split logic and feel free to comment below!  

 All the best for your project! 

 Philipp

 Product Owner SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit Direct Transfer

entry.title: Latest Features in the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit, released with 2025 FPS0
entry.content:
Introducing the Latest Features in the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA

We're pleased to introduce the newest features in the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit, released with SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS0 and SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition 2025 FPS0. These updates have been developed in direct response to customer feedback, aiming to elevate user experience and streamline migration processes.

New Staging and Direct Transfer Approach Features

Sequence Information View

A new feature is the Sequence Information View. This feature is designed to guide you in transferring data to your target system. It organizes migration objects in your project into a sequence for processing. This sequence is tailored to your specific project, depending on the migration objects you're working with.

By default, you'll see the Sequence Information View as your Start View, but you can easily switch back to the Standard View that you're used to.

Easier Access to Message Information

This improvement makes it simpler to navigate and access message-related information.

You can now easily trigger actions related to: 

  • Preparation Messages (only available for direct transfer): Get Information into the messages generated during Prepare Mapping Tasks.
  • Simulation Messages: Quickly access relevant information to better understand the outcomes of your simulation tasks.
  • Migration Messages: Get direct insights into the messages generated during the migration process, helping to troubleshoot and optimize your activities.
  • Migration Results: Access detailed information on the results of migration tasks, ensuring you have all the necessary data for review your migration tasks.

 These actions provide direct links to relevant message information, streamlining your navigation and increasing efficiency.

Server Group Assignment

This update offers you the ability to designate a specific application server or server group for your migration project, helping to ensure smooth operations without disrupting business activities.

To set this up, navigate go Job Management â€“ Job Settings under the Option for Project. Here, you can select the application server or server group (if available) that best fits your needs.

Job Management

You now can adjust the number of background jobs assigned to specific migration objects, this offering a flexibility to streamline your data migration process according to your project's requirements.

To utilize this feature, go to Job Management under Jobs Used for Migration Objects, there you can see how many jobs are assigned to each migration object in your project.

Migration objects are categorized as following:

  • No Constraints: You can adjust the number of jobs assigned to the migration object.
  • Selection Process Only (1 Job for Simulation / Migration): Some objects, such as CO â€“ Cost Center or CO â€“ Profit Center, are limited to one job, so job adjustments aren't possible for them.
  • Staging Tables Not Prepared: Before adjusting job numbers, complete the Preparation step for these objects. (available for staging approach)
  • Status "Not Ready for Processing": If an object has this status, adjustments to job assignments are not possible

 For Staging approach, you can find more details in SAP KBA 294684 - SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit: List of Migration objects that doesn't support parallel jobs 

New Staging Features

Optimize Migration Performance

Migrating large volumes of data can be more efficient if you break it down into smaller packages. Once you've completed the "Prepare" step, you'll receive a recommendation on the number of jobs that can simultaneously handle a specific migration task. In the Job Management section, you have the flexibility to modify the number of background jobs dedicated to migration objects.

Efficient Error Handling When Uploading Template Files

The staging approach has been enhanced to display all sanity, duplicate, and consistency errors at once. This improvement means you no longer need to re-upload your file after each individual correction.

Any errors that arise during file upload are now provided in the template file, collected in the new â€œMessagesâ€ tab. In addition, a cell reference is available for each message which leads you directly to the error. After error correction, you need to delete the â€œMessagesâ€ tab and can upload the template file again.

See also following blog: SAP S/4HANA Migration cockpit: Easier Error Handling 

Correction File After Simulation

After a simulation ends with errors, you now have the option to use the "Create Correction File" action. This feature generates a file containing the specific instances of data that encountered errors during simulation.

This makes it straightforward to edit the issue-prone data within the file and re-upload it to the staging tables, like the Correction file feature available after Migration.

Download Template File (LTMOM)

You now have the capability to download Migration Object Template Files as CSV files, not only in the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit but also in SAP S/4HANA migration object Modeler (LTMOM).

 

New Direct Transfer (DT) Approach Features

Object Versions

The system will update the status of a migration object when a new version is available. While new versions of migration objects will contain new features or bug fixes, migration objects can also be deprecated or retired. The system will also update the status of such migration objects to inform you that they will be unavailable in future releases.

Define Split Logic (LTMOM)

To generate multiple entries in the target parameter for each entry in a source table, you can define a split. There are two types of split logic available to tailor this process to your needs:

  • Simple Split Logic
  • Advanced Split Logic

 For more detailed information please see:

  • SAP Note: 3595079 Defining Split Logic - SAP S/4HANA Migration Object Modeler , especially the detailed guide attached
  • Blog from Philipp Kreutzheide: SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit â€“ Migrate Directly from SAP â€“ Increase flexibility using Split Logic

Event Based Rules (LTMOM)

Event-based rules offer the capability to execute ABAP code at specific point of processing. To set up an event-based rule, you need to map a source table to a target parameter. Moreover, the target parameter must be a table, or a structure of type Importing, Changing, or Tables.

Class Based Source Code Rules (LTMOM)

Class-based source code rules offer an advanced option for defining how source values are transformed to target values. By creating an ABAP class with your own logic, you can create a class-based source code rule that utilizes this class. Additionally, these rules allow you to directly call other rules within the source code.

Utilizing Where Conditions Editor (LTMOM)

The WHERE Conditions Editor enables you to define additional selection criteria across all fields in a table using Open SQL statements. You can use AND and OR operations to build simple or complex conditions. You can leverage all ABAP Dictionary data types, with the exception of STRING, RAWSTRING, LCHR, and LRAW.

More details you can find in SAP KBA 3249988 - Details on selection process - SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit - Direct Transfer

Instance Field List (LTMOM)

You can define how migration object instance is displayed in the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit. They are available under Instance List Settings button on the detailed screen for your root table.)

New Migration Objects

For details on the new migration objects, please check:

  • SAP S/4HANA â€“ Release Comparison of Migration Object Templates (Staging Table)
  • SAP S/4HANA - Release Comparison of Migration Objects (Direct Transfer)

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit: Adapt the XML file to your business needs
entry.content:
When using the staging approach for your data migration, you often face the challenge that the provided XML file contains sheets and columns within the sheets that are not relevant for your business needs.

Did you know that it is possible to adjust the XML files easily?

However, before I go to the possible options, note that you must be careful when deleting, as any change can corrupt the XML structure. There is also no guarantee that such a tailored XML file can still be used after upgrading to a higher release.

After creating a migration project in the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit using the Migrate Your Data app select Download Template in Action for a specific migration object and choose File Type â†’ XML file.

Note 

The description below is for Microsoft Excel. The procedure may differ when using another spreadsheet program than Microsoft Excel.

Option 1: Delete a non-mandatory sheet

Open the downloaded file and choose Enable Editing button. Select a non-mandatory sheet you want to delete â€“ choose the context menu by clicking on your mouse and choose "Delete".

 Confirm on the follow up pop-up you want to delete.

Proceed in this way with all the non-mandatory sheets that you want to delete.

Note

You can only delete non-mandatory sheets and delete sheets even though the worksheet contains mandatory columns. This is because there is no need to fill the mandatory columns in the sheet with data if the sheet itself is not relevant for your project.

Option 2:  Delete a non-mandatory column within a sheet

First, you need to unprotect the sheet. So, you need to select a sheet where you want to delete one column or more columns â€“ choose the context menu by clicking right on your mouse and select â€œUnprotect Sheetâ€.

Select the column(s) you want to delete â€“ in my example all columns for Tax Calculation Brazil. Choose "Delete".

Note

Alternatively, you can go to File â†’ Info â†’ Protect Workbook area and click on Unprotect for the sheets you want to make changes on.

Save your changes. You can now fill your XML file as usual and load the data into the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit.

When you upload your data, the tool informs you that the Validation Completed with Warnings.  

To be able to view the messages, choose "Show Messages" you get a list of all messages occurred during Validation.

In this case, warnings are displayed because the fields deleted in the previous steps are missing from the sheet. 

 To load the data into the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit select your file and transfer the data via Actions â†’ Transfer Data to Staging Tables.

 The instances will be loaded into the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit staging tables.

You can now proceed with your data migration steps as usual.

 Using CSV files

Like the XML file, you can easily tailor your CSV files  as you only need to use the files for the structures and fields you want to process. Just provide the files for mandatory structures and the structures you need. Within the files you must also only provide the mandatory fields and the fields you need. All the other fields you can remove.  A CSV file has much less administrative data than an XML file. The 100 MB limit is the same, but with tailored CSV files the http-protocol related size limit is not reached that fast as using XML files.

entry.title: The New Explore Migration Objects App, The Game Changer in Planning Your Data Migration
entry.content:
A Short Trip to History

Since people have been performing data migrations into different systems, they have wanted to know the dependencies between the various data they need to migrate. They usually create project plans, PowerPoint presentations, or use tools like Visio to make these dependencies visible. As the saying goes, a picture is worth a thousand words. Since SAP began delivering preconfigured data migration objects, initially as a Rapid Deployment Solution for SAP ECC, later for SAP S/4HANA, and then as migration objects for the SAP S/4HANA Migration Cockpit, customers have repeatedly asked for an overview diagram of the dependencies of these objects.

Initially, when the number of migration objects was manageable, there was an attempt to create an overview diagram in Visio. The interim result, shown in Figure 1, reflects only a portion of the objects present at that time. Each additional object made the diagram increasingly confusing.

Paper Draft

Figure 1, Paper Draft

The data initially resembled a sewing machine pattern or the London Tube Map, making it unusable.

Since the data was already in the system, the dependencies of a migration object were listed in the SAP Help Portal documentation. Customers could view them there. Later, this information was also included in the overview list of "Available Migration Objects."

There have always been efforts to provide customers with an interactive map. Initially, we considered displaying it on a web page using Python's network graph tool. However, this approach failed due to technical, hosting, and maintenance problems.

The Tile of Happiness

After a long wait filled with much effort, numerous usability tests with internal and external consultants, and feedback from customers, we are proud to present the first version of the Explore Migration Objects app. Internally, we refer to it as the EMO app.

The idea to use the SAP Fiori Network Graph and offer it in an easy-to-use app was a decisive turning moment. We began with an initial draft version and conducted several usability tests to determine users' needs and the desired design. Based on the test results, we finalized the app and delivered it through CFD and a feature toggle in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.3. In SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602, the app is available without a feature toggle.

Spoiler: In the near future, users may choose between an "empty" tile and a tile that shows the number of available migration objects delivered by SAP within the current release.

 

 

 




Figure 2, The Tiles

How does the app support data migration?

The app assists you with planning your data migrations. It provides a graphical overview of data migration objects and their mandatory or optional predecessor objects. This offers a complete view of the entire data migration scope or individual subareas. You can quickly identify necessary dependent predecessor migration objects. Additionally, you can navigate from each migration object to its documentation on the SAP Help Portal. This makes it easier and faster to familiarize yourself with the details of a migration object.

It helps you plan your data migration scope and the sequence to extract and load your data. You can also determine data migration objects by entering a scope item (business process) to see which migration objects are assigned to it. This helps you check if your planned scope covers all data migration objects or identify which objects might be relevant.

The app is continually enhanced with new functionality in future releases. However, as data migrations in SAP S/4HANA and Private Cloud are not assigned to scope items, this functionality is not supported in those product versions.

For which product and release is the version available, and how do you activate it?

The Explore Migration Objects app (F8638) is available with SAP S/4HANA versions 2508.3 and 2508.4. To activate it, enable the feature Enable new app for Explore Migration objects (CFND_DMCC_NEW_APP_EXPLORE_01).

For more details on activating apps through features, please refer to the What's New Document on the SAP Help Portal

With SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602, the app is generally available in the data migration group without needing activation. For SAP S/4HANA and Private Cloud, the app is available with SAP S/4HANA 2025FPS1. However, for SAP S/4HANA 2023 or earlier releases, the app is not available. These products are already in the support package phase, and new features and apps may only be delivered during the feature pack phase.

What authorization do I need?

If you already have authorization for the SAP S/4HANA migration cockpit, you can use this app too.

Which approaches are supported?

The first version of the app currently supports only the migration objects built for the Staging Tables approach. Support for the Direct Transfer approach (DT) is planned for later versions as the framework for that approach is enhanced with additional functionality.

Where can I find the app?

The app is assigned to the Data Migration page. Especially during the controlled feature delivery phase in version 2508.4, you may need to search for the app by its name and assign it to your page manually.

Data Migration GroupFigure 3, Data Migration Group

How do I use the app?

Selecting the data

The app is structured like most SAP Fiori apps: it includes a selection area and a result area. The selection area displays three different selection fields:

  1. A "Search" field where you can enter a freely defined search string.
  2. A "Migration Object" field where you can enter or select one or more migration objects.
  3. A "Scope Item" field where you can select one or more scope items.

Selection area

Figure 4, Selection area

The results area shows the results of your selection based on the selection field where you entered your search term. It is divided into one area by two tab bars to display migration objects and scope items in a table. When you enter a search string into the search field, the system returns all migration objects and scope items that contain that search string. 

Some Example

For example, if you enter "Asset" into the search field, it returns all migration objects containing that search string. When you enter or select a value in the â€œMigration Objectâ€ field, a proposal list first appears. You can then select values from this list.

Result area, Migration Objects Tab
Figure 5, Result area, Migration Objects Tab

You can also use the value help to search and select one or multiple objects.

Migration Objects Field, Value Help

Figure 6,  Migration Objects Field, Value Help

If you select the "Go" button or press the Enter key, the system displays the result. This result differs from what you obtain through the search field. Searching with the "Migration Object" field provides relevant migration objectsâ€¦

Result area, Migration Objects Tab

 Figure 7, Result area, Migration Objects Tab

â€¦and the scope items to which these objects are assigned.

Result area, Scope Items Tab

Figure 8, Result area, Scope Items Tab

When you search using the "Scope Item" field, the "Migration Objects" tab lists all migration objects assigned to these scope items. You can find the related scope items on the "Scope Items" tab.

You can combine the "Search" field with either the â€œMigration Objectâ€ field or the â€œScope Itemâ€ field. However, do not use the â€œMigration Objectâ€ field and the â€œScope Itemâ€ field together. The search results vary based on which of the three search fields you complete. 

Now, let's focus on the most important aspect: what you can actually do with it in the app.

The graphical overview for migration objects

Search for the Migration Object "Material BOM", and select it from the result list. The selection view changes to display the â€œMigration Objectâ€ view. The migration object "Material BOM" and its alias (BOM_3) appear in the title section. The migration object and its dependent predecessor objects are shown as nodes within a network diagram. Each object appears as a blue node within a group that indicates the migration domain to which the migration object belongs. "Material BOM" is assigned to a domain called "Basic Data." The domain name is derived from the application component description to which the object belongs. You can see the alias and the technical name of the component within the blue node. The alias is a technical construct that is part of the technical name of a data migration object. Knowing the alias name of a migration object can be very useful.

Network GraphFigure 9, Network Graph

Connectors illustrate the relationships between migration objects. Upon closer inspection, you'll notice different types of connectors linking the objects. Dashed gray lines represent connections to optional predecessor migration objects. Solid orange lines indicate mandatory predecessor objects, such as "Product" in the example shown.

Network Graph Connectors

Figure 10, Network Graph Connectors

Functions

The toolbar displays various fields and functions. It includes a search field where users can enter a string to find an object in larger network diagrams and navigate to that object.

Initially, the direction of the objects runs from left to right. This means the root object is on the left side, and all others are arranged to the right. Use the â€œTransposeâ€ button to change the direction from left-right to top-bottom. This can sometimes make it easier to get an overview of larger diagrams or take a better screenshot.

Next to the â€œTransposeâ€ button is the â€œLegendâ€ button, which displays the legend. Next to it, you can find the zoom buttons. You can either zoom in or zoom out. Between the two buttons, the zoom factor is displayed as a percentage. Next to the zoom area is the "Zoom to Fit" button. It zooms the diagram so that all nodes are displayed on the screen.

ToolbarFigure 11, Toolbar

The "Enter to Full Screen" button displays the diagram in a separate window. In some browsers with built-in screenshot functionality, such as Microsoft Edge or Firefox, it's sometimes useful to switch to full screen before taking a screenshot.

Directly to the right of the toolbar, you'll find the graph overview. Some users may already be familiar with this feature from other applications or the ABAP Dictionary transaction SE11. In SE11, you could display a graphical overview of tables and their dependencies, where it was called the navigation area. The graph overview helps prevent losing track in very large network diagrams. It always shows the complete network diagram in a small window. A small blue window within the graph overview indicates the current section of the diagram displayed on the screen. You can move the blue window to the section you want to display.

Graph OverviewFigure 12, Graph Overview

Interactions on a node

Clicking on a node opens a menu. This menu offers options to expand or collapse the predecessor structure of the migration objects or to display the links popover.

Interactions on a node

Figure 13, Interactions on a node

In the links popover, accessible through the "Node Links" icon   , you find the direct link to the documentation of the migration object on SAP Help Portal. Future versions may also include links to available sample data for the migration object. These samples are already provided on the SAP Help Portal.

Documentation LinksFigure 14, Documentation Links

Similar to a node, you can also collapse   or expand  a group. When collapsed, the group displays only its name.

Collapse Group
Figure 15, Collapse Group

You can use the Group Details icon   to view all migration objects assigned to a collapsed group. If the main object is in a collapsed group, a home icon appears in front of its name.

Group Details IconFigure 16, Group Details Icon

Clicking on a connector or the area surrounding it calls up the connector's detail popover.

Connector's detail popoverFigure 17, Connector's detail popover

You can expand each migration object that has a predecessor object to display these predecessor objects. Simply click the "Expand Migration Objects" icon  .

Figure 18, Expand Migration Objects

The graphical overview for scope items

In this example, we use "Asset" as the search term for the scope items, then select â€œ1IHâ€ â€“ "Intercompany Asset Transfer Within Same Country". The functionality of the "Scope Items" view matches that of the view for migration objects. The scope item node appears as a circular shape. Each migration object connects to the scope item in the first release of the app with a solid orange line. In future versions, this solid line changes to a dashed gray line to clarify that such objects aren't mandatory for a scope item.

Network graph Scope ItemFigure 19, Network graph Scope Item

More to Come: A Short Outlook on Ideas

Several additional features are planned or under discussion. One example is an option to display either all available objects delivered by SAP with a release or only the activated migration objects. The latter option shows the same objects that customers see when selecting an object within the migration cockpit. Migration objects assigned to a non-standard scope item that is not activated will not be shown. The same applies to migration objects available only if a business function, such as retail-related objects, is activated.

There are also discussions about displaying the migration object type, indicating whether it is a master data or transaction data object. Additionally, there are plans to show whether a migration object supports key user extensibility.

Once the Direct Transfer approach framework expands to support the EMO app, these migration objects and their dependencies are expected to be available with the app.

Since almost all usability testers saw no need for a download or print function, such a function is not currently planned. Instead, you can use the integrated screenshot functionality provided in several web browsers, such as Firefox and Edge on Microsoft Windows and Apple macOS.

Outlook on SAP S/4HANA and SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud

The EMO app is available with SAP S/4HANA 2025 FPS1. It offers almost the same functionality as the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508.3/2602 app. However, the scope item functionality isn't available for SAP S/4HANA because migration objects within SAP S/4HANA aren't assigned to scope items. Functions provided within SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition CFD or main releases are likely added to SAP S/4HANA FPS2 and FPS3.

Feel free to share your opinions about the app in the comments section of this blog. You can also suggest new functions and features you might be missing.

P.S. My personal kudo goes to @vishnuvardhantanguturu, Miller Li, Zak Zhang, and @Martina_H, my colleagues in development and product management that worked hard in the last 9 months to deliver the baby in time. Special Thanks also to Joshua Sturm, for checking the blog text before delivery.
